title: Frontend vs Backend
description: Learn what runs in the browser and what runs on the server

content.question: Which of the following technologies runs in the user's web browser?
content.explanation: JavaScript, HTML, and CSS are the core frontend technologies. They run directly in the user's browser to create the visual interface and interactivity. Python, databases, and Node.js all run on a server (the backend).

title: APIs — How Apps Talk
description: Discover how applications communicate using APIs, HTTP methods, and JSON

content.question: What does an API do in web development?
options: It lets different software applications communicate with each other
It styles the appearance of a website
It stores files on a hard drive
It compiles code into machine language
content.explanation: An API (Application Programming Interface) is a set of rules that allows different software programs to talk to each other. Think of it like a waiter in a restaurant: you (the frontend) tell the waiter (the API) what you want, the waiter takes your order to the kitchen (the backend), and brings back your food (the data).

content.prompt: Complete this JavaScript code to make a GET request to an API endpoint and parse the JSON response.

hints: This built-in browser function is used to make HTTP requests
This method parses the response body as JSON

content.prompt: Match each HTTP method to what it does
Put these steps of an API request/response cycle in the correct order
items: User clicks a button in the browser
Frontend JavaScript sends an HTTP request to the API endpoint
The server receives the request and processes it
The server queries the database for the needed data
The server sends back an HTTP response with JSON data
The frontend receives the response and updates the page
content.explanation: When a user interacts with a web app, the frontend sends an HTTP request to the server. The server processes it (often querying a database), then sends a response back. Finally, the frontend uses that response to update what the user sees.

content.sentence: An HTTP status code of _____ means the request was successful, while a code of _____ means the resource was not found.

content.explanation: We access response.status which is 201, then response.body.name which is "Alice". The dot notation lets us dig into nested objects to get specific values. Status code 201 means "Created" — a new resource was successfully made.

title: Serverless & Edge Computing
description: Explore modern deployment models — from traditional servers to serverless functions and the edge

content.question: What is the main idea behind 'serverless' computing?
options: You write code as small functions, and the cloud provider manages all the servers for you
There are literally no servers involved — code runs on the user's device only
You must buy and maintain your own physical servers
Code is stored in the browser and never touches a server
content.explanation: Despite the name, serverless does use servers! The key difference is that YOU don't manage them. You just write your function code, upload it, and the cloud provider (like AWS or Cloudflare) handles starting servers, scaling up when traffic increases, and shutting down when idle. You only pay for the time your code actually runs.

content.prompt: Match each concept to its description

pairs.right: An always-running machine you manage and pay for 24/7
Code that runs on-demand and scales automatically
Delay when a serverless function starts after being idle
Running code in data centers close to the user
A network that caches and delivers static files globally

content.prompt: Put these steps in order: What happens when a user's request hits a serverless function that has been idle?
items: A user in Tokyo makes a request to your API
The request is routed to the nearest edge location or cloud region
The cloud provider notices no instance is running (cold start begins)
A new container or isolate is created and your function code is loaded
Your function executes and processes the request
The response is sent back to the user
content.explanation: When a serverless function hasn't been used recently, the cloud provider needs to spin up a new instance — this is the 'cold start'. The request is routed to the best location, a fresh runtime is created, your code loads and runs, and then the response goes back to the user. Subsequent requests are faster because the instance is already warm.

content.sentence: A _____ is a network of servers spread around the world that caches content close to users, while _____ computing goes further by running your actual code at those locations.

questions.question: What is the key advantage of the edge model shown on the right?
options: Code runs close to users worldwide, reducing latency
It uses only one server, which is simpler
It does not require any code to be written
It is always cheaper than a traditional server
questions.answer: Code runs close to users worldwide, reducing latency

questions.question: In the traditional model on the left, what happens for a user in Sydney when the server is in New York?
options: Their request travels a long distance, causing higher latency
A new server is automatically created in Sydney
Sydney users get a different version of the app
questions.answer: Their request travels a long distance, causing higher latency
